title: Protocol for early warning of Diaporthe infection in kiwifruit soft rot by plasmonic dimer-enhanced Raman spectroscopy
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Synthesis of gold nanoparticles by the citrate reduction method
Timing: 4 h
This step describes in detail the synthesis of 40 nm gold nanoparticles (GNPs) by citrate acid reduction method (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). The selection of GNPs with this size is a comprehensive consideration of particle stability, synthesis repeatability and scattering intensity in the dark field.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4],5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2717-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Schematic diagram of synthesis of gold nanoparticles by the citrate reduction method
Prepare aqua regia with a ratio 3:1 (v:v) concentrated HCl:HNO3 in the fume hood.
Critical: Be careful when configuring aqua regia, and take protective measures during operation to prevent it from splashing on the body. It is necessary to wear special acid-resistant gloves, goggles and a lab coat, and try to avoid skin exposure. Meanwhile, aqua regia needs fresh configuration and should not be sealed, otherwise it may cause explosion.
Soak the conical flask in the fume hood with freshly prepared aqua regia for 30 min, then rinse it with Milli-Q water, and dry for later use.
Add 98.9 mL of water and 1 mL of trisodium citrate solution (30 mg/mL) to a clean conical flask on a hotplate.
Add the stirrer bar into the conical flask, and turn on the rotate and heating switches of the hotplate (Temperature set at 300°C, speed set at 23 × g).
When the solution starts to boil, add 0.1 mL of 250 mM HAuCl4·4H20, keep the condition above and continue stirring for 7 min.
Cool the above seed solution with ice, and store it at 4°C.

Note: The seed solution can be spherical under transmission electron microscopy (TEM), with a diameter of approximately 13 nm (12–15 nm). Otherwise, it can be simply judged by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy. The surface plasmon resonance peak is near 520 nm, and the corresponding absorbance is 1.022.
Use the seed-growth method to synthesize 40 nm GNPs. Detailed steps are as follows:
Mix together 9.4 mL seed solution, 10 mL water, 0.2 mL NH2OH·HCl (100 mM) and 0.2 mL trisodium citrate (10 mg/mL) in a clean conical flask on a magnetic stirrer.
Add the stirrer bar into the conical flask, and turn on the rotate switch of the hotplate (Temperature set at 300°C, speed set at 23 × g, time set 5 min).
Add 0.4 mL 1% HAuCl4·4H2O to the solution above and continue stirring for 1 h.
Repeat step 7 three times to get the final GNPs solution as vector for nanoprobes’ construction.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2717-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Characterization of 40 nm gold nanoparticles
(A) Surface plasmon resonance peak showed by absorption spectrum.
(B) Spherical morphology showed by the TEM.
Note: The seed solution should be spherical under transmission electron microscopy (TEM), with a diameter of approximately 40 nm (38–42 nm). Otherwise, it can be simply judged by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy. The surface plasmon resonance peak is near 526 nm, and the corresponding absorbance is 2.272. Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] shows an example of UV-Visible spectra (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A) and morphology (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B) of the final 40 nm GNPs.
Pause point: The prepared 40 nm GNPs can be stored at 4°C for 4 months. But remember not to freeze, which may lead to the aggregation of GNPs and affect further use.

Note: The single-particle scattering theory proposed that the particle sizes of GNP are positively related to its scattered light intensity; the particles with small sizes are hardly observed in the dark field accordingly. Although GNPs with larger particle size can provide stronger scattering light and better SERS enhancement, they are unstable, especially modified by DNA. The 40 nm nanoparticles meet the reasonable scattering intensity, stability, and SERS enhancement design objectives.
Construction of nanoprobes
Timing: 3 days
This step provides the synthesis of nanoprobes, including the screen of target DNA, modification of Raman reporter molecules (DTNB, 4-MBA) on gold nanoparticles and the modification of DNA (Helper DNA, primer DNA) by salt-aging method.
Obtain ITS sequences from the NCBI GenBank and align them to determine the conserved and variable regions of the Diaporthe genus.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2717-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Screening the primer DNA for Diaporthe genus
This figure is quoted from Yu et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Note: The complementary sequence of the screened sequence is designed as primer DNA (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Note: If the target DNA screened by the two species is significantly different, we can design the capture DNA for them respectively, and use the two kinds of capture DNA for the modification of the nanoprobe at the same time. In this way, when either target DNA of the two species is added to the system, there will be corresponding capture DNA react with it.
Soak the vials in the fume hood with freshly prepared aqua regia for 30 min, then rinse it with Milli-Q water.
Soak with 0.1 M NaOH for 30 min and dry for later use.
Note: It's better soak with NaOH, because GNPs will adhere to the wall during a long incubation in the vials, and soaking with NaOH can well solve this problem.

Modification of Raman reporter molecules (DTNB, 4-MBA) on GNPs.
Add DTNB and 4-MBA to 1 mL GNP solution until the final concentration is 250 mM respectively, keep at room temperature for 2 h.
Add 100 μL 0.1% SDS and centrifuge the solution (1680 × g, 20 min).
Wash three times to remove excessive reagents.
Redisperse the precipitate in 1 mL water for DNA modification.
Modify DNA (helper DNA, primer DNA) on GNPs by salt-aging method.
Note: Salt-aging is chosen because this method of functionalization with nucleic acids has been well established.6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
Add 1 μL 1 mM TCEP to thiol-modified primer DNA and helper DNA (100 μM) in microcentrifuge tubes for 1 h.
Note: The purpose of adding TCEP is to reduce disulfide bonds that may be produced during DNA storage.
Add Primer 1 and primer 2 to DTNB and MBA modified GNPs respectively, the helper DNA added is in four times the amount of primer DNA.
Put the vials in a shaker incubate overnight at 37°C, 0.5 × g.
The next morning (10 h), add 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) and 0.1% SDS to the solution with final concentration of 0.01 M and 0.01%.
For the next 10 h, add 2 M NaCl to the above solution at 2-h intervals with a final concentration of 0.2 M, followed by shaking overnight (10 h).
Transfer the solution into the centrifuge tube. Centrifuge the solution (1680 × g, 20 min).
Wash three times to remove excessive reagents.
Redispersed the precipitate in 1 mL water for target DNA detection.

Figure 4. Characterization of nanoprobes
(A) Zeta potential obtained by dynamic light scattering, showing a decrease in average surface charge.

(B) Average size obtained by dynamic light scattering, showing an increase in hydrodynamic diameter. The error bars represent the standard deviations of experiments in triplicate. This figure is quoted from Yu et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Note: There is no correspondence between Raman reporter molecules and primer DNA, we just need two Raman reporter molecules and two primer DNA to be connected separately, and you can combine them according to the actual situation. The connection of Raman reporter molecule and DNA can be verified by the corresponding change of zeta-potential (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A) and average size (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Note: DNA ligation efficiency can be improved by adjusting the frequency and the amount of NaCl added each time. By reducing the amount of NaCl added each time and increasing the total number of times, the efficiency can be improved, but when the total amount is too high, it will cause aggregation.
Optimizing the amount of primer DNA on gold nanoparticles on GNPs
Timing: 2 h
This step mainly shows the aggregation state induced by different ratio of primer DNA/helper DNA and how to estimate the conjugation number of effective primer DNA on each GNP by FAM modified primer 1 complementary strand.
Carry out statistical analysis in the dark field under different ratio of primer DNA/ helper DNA (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).

Figure 5. Optimization under different ratio of primer DNA/helper DNA
(A) Statistical results of target-induced aggregation of the plasmonic nanoprobes modified by different ratio of primer DNA/helper DNA.
(B) Estimation of effective DNA on each GNP with different ratio of primer DNA/ helper DNA. The error bars represent the standard deviations of experiments in triplicate. This figure is quoted from Yu et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Note: For detailed steps, please refer to dark-field imaging.

Prepare 400 nM, 425 nM, 450 nM, 475 nM and 500 nM FAM-complementary strand solution.
Add 200 μL the above solution into a micro cuvette to measure the fluorescence intensity, respectively.
Use origin 2019 for linear fitting to build fluorescence quantitative curve.
Hybridize the complementary strand labeled by FAM with nanoprobe by annealing treatment.
Centrifuge the reacted solution (1680 × g, 20 min) and collect the supernatant.
Take 200 μL supernatant and measure its fluorescence intensity in the Fluoro Spectrophotometer.
Note: The measure intensity comes from non-hybridized complementary strand in the supernatant.
Calculate the concentration of the non-hybridized complementary strand to convert concentration of the hybridized complementary strand.
Define the amount of primer DNA that can be hybridized on each GNP as hybridization efficiency (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B), the calculation formula is as follows:

Note: In order to generate dimers rather than aggregates as much as possible, it is necessary to ensure that the number of primer DNA on a single GNP. For the 40 nm GNP we used here, the optimal number of primer DNA is about 5. For particles with different shapes and sizes, it should be optimized according to the actual situation. Try to avoid too many and too little. Too many is easy to cause large aggregates, while too little is not easy to form dimers.

Note: Single particle does not produce hot spots, so there is no SERS signal enhancement; Large aggregates are mainly caused by the inevitable repeated washing in the experiment, it means large aggregates represent false positive signals; Plasmonic dimers are the main signal source in the experiment. Therefore, the purpose of optimization is to produce more plasmonic dimers rather than large aggregates.
Pathogen DNA extraction
Timing: 4 h
This step mainly introduces how to extract the DNA of pathogen by improved CTAB method.
Take fresh hyphae on the flat plate and put them in a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube in the clean bench.
Add liquid nitrogen and grind them into powder with a grinding rod.
Add 600 μL of 2× CTAB solution preheated to 65°C and mix them upside down.
Then take a water bath at 65°C for 30 min and cool to room temperature.
Add 600 μL mixed solution of chloroform and isoamyl alcohol with a ratio of 24: 1 (v/v), shake the solution and centrifuge at 6740 × g for 10 min.
Take the supernatant into another 1.5 mL tube, add mixed solution of chloroform and isoamyl alcohol (v/v 24:1), mix and centrifuge at 6740 × g for 10 min.
Take the supernatant into another tube, add 0.6 times the volume of precooled isopropanol, mix it gently.
Keep at −20°C for 1 h and centrifuge at 6740 × g for 10 min.
Remove the supernatant and add 70% absolute ethanol to wash twice.
Dry at room temperature, dissolve the precipitated DNA with an appropriate amount of sterile ddH2O
Note: Generally, the storage time is about 1 month when stored at −20°C.
Extracting DNA from kiwi fruit
Timing: 1 h

This step shows in detail how to extract DNA from diseased kiwi fruits by using the Baifeite genomic DNA extraction kit.
Grind the diseased part of kiwifruit into fine powder in liquid nitrogen, put it into a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube.
Add 1 mL of solution A into the tube, swirl it to make the sample completely dispersed in the solution and take a water bath (65°C, 10 min).
Add 300 μL solution B and 200 μL chloroform solution into the centrifuge tube, swirl for 30 s and centrifuge at 12000 × g for 5 min.
Take the supernatant into another centrifuge tube, add equal volume of solution C, fully mix evenly.
Add the mixture to the DNA adsorption column, and centrifuge at 12000 × g for 1 min at room temperature.
Remove the waste liquid from the collection tube, add 500 μL rinsing liquid and repeat the centrifugal rinsing step.
Put the DNA adsorption column in an empty collection tube, and centrifuge at room temperature of 12000 × g for 2 min.
Put the adsorption column in a DNase-free centrifuge tube, add 50 μL of DNA eluent in the middle part of the adsorption membrane.
Keep at room temperature for 5 min, then centrifuge at 12000 × g for 2 min.
Collect the solution in the centrifuge tube as the extracted DNA sample.
Note: Generally, the storage time is about 1 month when stored at −20°C.
Note: Pathogen DNA and Kiwi fruit DNA are interrupted by ultrasonic cell grinder before SERS detection. The parameters are as follows: ice bath, power 85%, ultrasonic 3 s, interval 6 s, total ultrasonic treatment for 40 min.
Capture of target DNA
Timing: 2 h
This step mainly introduces the binding operation of nanoprobes and target DNA.

Dilute the two nanoprobes to 100 pM with water.
Note: The concentration of the nanoprobes can be estimated by comparing with the intensity change of the GNPs in the UV-vis absorption spectroscopy.
Add 50 μL of the each diluted two nanoprobes into a 200 μL tube, then add 50 μL of target DNA with different concentration after ultrasonic interruption.
Place the tube in the Mini dry bath, after heating to 95°C, keep it for 3 min, then slowly cool down to room temperature.

(A) SERS spectra of different concentrations of target.

Dark-field imaging
Timing: 4 h
This step introduces the cleaning steps of the glass slide and the dark field imaging operation in detail.
Fix the nanoprobes on the slide glass for dark field imaging experiment. The detailed steps for cleaning the slide glass are as follows:
Note: The purpose of cleaning slide glass is to reduce the influence of impurities and dust in the dark field.
Clean the slide glass with detergent for 5 min, then rinse it with water. Put in an oven for drying.
Take out the slide, immerse it in acetone solution, and sonicate for 30 min.
Immerse the slide in ethanol and water in turn, and the same ultrasonic and oven-dry treatment is performed.

Prepare the piranha solution in a beaker with the ratio of concentrated sulfuric acid to 30% hydrogen peroxide of 7: 3 (v/v).
Put the glass slide in the beaker, and heat the piranha solution for 1 h.
Take out the slide glass and rinse it with plenty of ultrapure water, and store it for later use after drying.
Note: When preparing piranha solution, pay attention to adding concentrated sulfuric acid first and then slowly adding hydrogen peroxide, otherwise it may cause explosion. The used piranha solution should be cooled first, and then put the solution in the fume hood for a period of time to ensure that all gases are diffused, so that the remaining sulfuric acid is not too strong. The catalytic amount of Mn can be added here, because it can catalyze the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. Then carefully add the acid into water to dilute it into dilute sulfuric acid. After that, it can be disposed conventionally.
React the nanoprobe with the target DNA, dilute it 50 times and drop it on the slide, place it for 10 min and wash the slide with ultrapure water.

(C and D) Histogram of the SERS intensity at 1071 cm−1 and 1326 cm−1, respectively, produced by the DNA samples from different Fungal isolates. SXJY2-1, CDHY1-1, GZHY3-1 belong to Diaporthe genus, while GZHY3-1 belong to Alternaria sp., WZBLN2-2 belong to Botryosphaeria sp., HBRZ2 -5 belong to Penicillium sp. The error bars represent the standard deviations of repeated experiments. This figure is quoted from Yu et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Select single-stranded and double-stranded target DNA for statistical comparison with the particle aggregation without target DNA in dark field (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B).
Select the pathogen from Diaporthe and the non-target genus respectively for specificity test (Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C and 8D).
Note: It can be seen from Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] that there are individual base differences among different species used for screening primer DNA. Therefore, slight SERS signal difference may occur when the target DNA from different species of the Diaporthe genus is detected. However, this does not affect the result of SERS detection, because compared with the control group, all the target DNA from this genus caused significant SERS signal enhancement.
SERS measurement of actual samples
Timing: 2 h
This part mainly introduces the steps of SERS detection.
Infect kiwifruit with pathogens belongs to Diaporthe genus.

(B and C) SERS spectra of control group (B) and infected group (C) at different point in time from 0 h to 96 h with an interval 12 h. The shaded area around each spectral line represented the 95% confidence interval, for each group, n = 15.

Note: Select other pathogens of non-Diaporthe genus to infect kiwifruit as control. The optical image records the fruit state at different infection time (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A).
According to step 29, extract DNA of kiwifruit with different infection time from infected fruit.
Perform SERS measurements on the extracted DNA, the detailed steps can be referred to capture of target DNA and Raman sensing performance.
Note: The difference of SERS signal between the infected group and the control group proves the successful detection (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]B–9E).
